Literally my favorite game of all time. 

The art, the story, the world you explore is so expertly crafted. Dark, moody, and sarcastic protagonist with so many interesting characters along the way.. you can really get lost in its creator's imagination.  Andrzej Sapkowski created a very unique world with plenty of polish folklore charm and this game brings it to life. 

The latest update to this game puts it far ahead in graphic quality to many games out even this year. With over 150 hours of content from the main game and its two stellar DLCs, you can replay the game a month after finishing and it still feels fresh. The DLCs also allow you to approach both new stories separate from the main game, which really underlines how the complete game is truly three in one. Each of the DLCs are better than many full offerings from other studios in both content and quality.

A huge community of modders (and the recent release of the devkit) makes for even more replay value. ~7.000 mods on nexus at this point, with more every week. And, if you have VR, check out vorpX for a whole new way to experience the game in 3D!

One of the most engaging stories I've ever witnessed. Amazingly human, relatable, endearing, sometimes funny, often serious, always well-written characters. The open-world is mesmerizing, filled to the brim with life, human or wild, side-quests that range from the funniest I've seen in an RPG to the darkest. OST is a masterpiece. Gameplay is good action-RPG mechanics, nothing too hard, but this fits a rather story-oriented game (as opposed to more "quiet" and gameplay-focused FromSoft titles for instance).

Deserved its GOTY in 2015, deserves its legendary status ten years later. Go play it!

The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is an incredible game that continues to impress even in 2024. The story is rich and captivating, pulling you into Geralt’s world with engaging characters and plots. The narrative is full of memorable moments that keep you invested throughout.

The combat remains fantastic and satisfying. It’s a blend of action and strategy that has aged remarkably well, making every fight feel intense and rewarding. Whether you’re battling a fearsome monster or outnumbered in a tough fight, the gameplay still holds up.

The landscapes in The Witcher 3 are absolutely stunning. The attention to detail in the environments creates a beautiful and immersive world that you’ll love exploring. The variety of monsters you encounter adds to the thrill, each one bringing its own unique challenge.

And don’t overlook Gwent—it’s seriously addictive and adds a lot of fun to the game. Whether you’re taking a breather from the main quests or just up for a bit of a challenge, Gwent’s a great way to keep things interesting. Overall, The Witcher 3 is an epic adventure that still stands out and is totally worth playing, even years after its release.

If you're a fan of story focused adventure then this is about the best there is. The world building, characters, and dialogue are top notch. Mechanically speaking it's relatively basic, but it's not a problem given that the story is what drives you forward. There were two decent issues however, the first being a slow start. The initial setting (white orchard / Velen) plays somewhat slow and it took me multiple revisits of this game before I could cross that threshold. The second issue is that it's very easy to get endings you don't want. To avoid this you would have to research nearly every decision just on the off chance that it changes how the story progresses. Even side quests will effect the fates of certain characters. It's almost as if the game is constructed specifically to give you unintended outcomes, so that you would replay it again. Normally I would have no problem with this, but the game is massive and long winded. I'm sure there are many people that wouldn't be fazed by this design however. 

9.3 / 10  A must play for story enthusiasts and a great template for what open world games should be.

Great game, a classic
Absolutely perfect. Everything about it is amazing. The story, characters, open world, soundtrack, gameplay, etc are all perfect. Not much more to say than that.

In short: the Witcher 3 is beautiful. Massive open-world, plotlines that weave in and out of each other, great voice-acting, consequential actions, a huge variety of gear, visceral and sometimes challenging combat, and well-crafted characters all come together to form an experience that feels alive and real. The graphics are plain beautiful, and the diversity of monsters is great; I'm often fascinated by them, and each Witcher contract feels interesting because of that. I initially intended to play the three Witcher games through in narrative order, but didn't end up doing that. As a result, whilst the game is perfectly accessible, I do find myself missing some context for certain events, lore or relationships (Yennefer and Triss being prime, spoiler-free  examples.)

I find combat between Geralt and other humanoids rather bland. In single combat, you just carve through anyone with ease and the same combination of moves; group combat is rendered challenging only due to the risk of mistiming an attack and getting struck by another enemy. The bosses are only a real struggle on Death March, such that the smallest mistake is really a death sentence, but going down to the next difficulty level is underwhelming. Often I only lose fights due to a misread or too much ambition, rather than genuinely being challenged. I must say that constantly doing tiny little tasks to get information or help is a little tedious; there's rarely a straight-forward quest, but when done well, it is immersive.

Masterpiece.

I was very new to gaming when this game was introduced to me, so the first thing that immediately made me like it, was the difficulty options you can choose from. It made it very clear that even without much experience this game could be for you.
After many many hours of playing I now decided to write a review to convince more people to play this game. 

Story:
The storytelling is amazing. You have a main quest/story line that branches off into many side quests/story lines and you find out a lot of things about Geralt of Rivia, his friends, his relationships and his enemy's. What I liked most is the different dialogue options and outcome options. Some outcomes you choose even influence future story lines and are incorporated, so you could play it more than once choosing different outcomes, difficulties and relationships. 

Graphics/World Exploring: 
The graphics of the game are just amazing. It feels like a realistic new world that you are captured into. Since the graphics are very nice it also makes a lot of fun to just run around the world to explore it. Loot houses, find hidden treasures, explore realistic looking caves and help people in need. Also it was a huge bonus to have a nice soundtrack playing in the background. The music changed for combat scenes, exploring and quests. It generally changed for most locations. 

Combat: 
As a beginner it was actually pretty easy to get into the fighting style used in this game. You have a short introduction into it, which honestly was enough to understand the basic fighting techniques. When you go on playing it gets easier due to oils, potions and more understanding of the monsters and their weaknesses. 

GWENT:
Gwent is the card game inside the game and I absolutely LOVED it. After fighting, the highlight was to find a Merchant or INN-keep and just ask them for a round of gwent. I need this game in real-life. 

I bought this game when it was on sale for a very small price, but it is definitely worth the full price. Not long after I started playing I bought both DLCs for full price, so I think that says a lot (I have not started playing them yet, but have only heard good things). 

All in all, I would totally recommend this game to beginners, amateurs and heavy gamers. Be aware that it does include blood, combat, nudity, foul language and sex - which I don't mind and it adds a lot to the game.

What stands out most is the storytelling. Whether it’s the main quest—Geralt’s journey to find Ciri or side quests, everything feels deeply personal. These aren’t your standard RPG fetch quests; they’re stories with emotional weight, often challenging your morals or surprising you with unexpected outcomes. It’s rare for a game to make you care so much about its world and characters, but The Witcher 3 pulls it off effortlessly.

What keeps you coming back is the world itself—sprawling, wild, and full of mystery. From the eerie, fog-covered swamps of Velen to the windswept islands of Skellige, every location is alive with history and atmosphere. The attention to detail is staggering, with every corner of the map feeling like it has a story to tell.

And at the heart of it all is Geralt—cynical yet compassionate, tired but unbreakable. His relationships, particularly with Ciri and Yennefer, ground the narrative in something deeply human, making the stakes feel real in a way that few games manage to capture. The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt  grabs hold of you and doesn’t let go. It’s an experience that stays with you.

TLDR: Highly reccomended

I wanted to get at least 100 hours in but fuck it. This is truly the perfect game, the story, characters, combat, and world are absolute perfection, the fact that past actions can have an effect later on is truly amazing, the different contracts and unique monster designs are so cool, the soundtrack is perfect and can make you feel so many things at once, the characters all have amazing writings and none of them ever feel bland, the open world is filled to the brim with content that actually means something and not stupid bullshit like Ubishit tends to do nowadays, it feels alive and you'll find yourself getting lost in it several times as you progress through the game, the story constantly has you invested and eager to see what happens next while never once leaving you bored or uninterested. The Witcher III is truly CD PROJECKT RED's magnum opus. This game came out in 2015 and holds up 9 years later. If you have not bought The Witcher III, I highly recommend you do so, you will end up having fun, I promise you.
